geographic_region: Southern Mexico; Oaxaca; many DO states
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate inflorescence c. 4-6 m; monocarpic; bat and insect pollinated
mezcal_use: Main cultivated mezcal agave; 6-8 year maturity; very widely planted
notes: Highly variable; source of most commercial mezcal and many hybrids
source: IUCN; Useful Tropical Plants; Kew POWO; Del Maguey espadÃ­n profile

geographic_region: SW Mexico; S Puebla to Veracruz and central Oaxaca
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike 3-5 m; monocarpic; produces many bulbils and seed
mezcal_use: High value wild and semi managed mezcal; sweet, floral spirits
notes: Restricted range and heavy wild harvest for mezcal
source: IUCN Red List 2020; Useful Tropical Plants; Kew POWO; UA Arboretum

geographic_region: Endemic to Oaxaca and Puebla
flowering_characteristics: Tall branched spike 6-8 m; monocarpic; bat pollinated
mezcal_use: Long maturing wild mezcal agave; intense savoury herbal mezcals
notes: Very long life cycle (20+ years) so highly sensitive to overharvest
source: IUCN 2019; People and Plants mezcal profile; Useful Tropical Plants

geographic_region: Southern Oaxaca karwinskii zone
roesette_pattern: trunk forming column with terminal rosette
flowering_characteristics: Tall spike 4-6 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Wild and semi wild mezcal agave; earthy, mineral, woody profiles
notes: Trunk forming habit used as living fences; many named landraces
source: EthnobiologÃ­a A. karwinskii; mezcal producer notes; Desert Museum agave ecology
producers: "Rey Campero,Gracias a Dios,Victorioso,Mezcal de Leyendas,El Jolgorio"

geographic_region: Oaxaca, especially MiahuatlÃ¡n
roesette_pattern: trunk forming column with large spherical rosette
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike to c. 6 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Highly prized mezcal agave; structured, mineral spirits
notes: Large piÃ±as up to a few hundred kilos when mature
source: NETA Spirits Madrecuixe profile; A. karwinskii management papers

geographic_region: Oaxaca karwinskii belt
roesette_pattern: slender trunk with barrel like rosette
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Wild and semi wild mezcal; spicy mineral profile
notes: Name refers to barrel shaped rosette on pole like stem
source: Karwinskii diversity studies; mezcal producer notes

geographic_region: Oaxaca
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Regional mezcal type; lean stony profile
notes: Name and morphology vary strongly by village
source: Traditional knowledge papers on A. karwinskii

geographic_region: Oaxaca
roesette_pattern: trunk forming column with long rosette
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Common karwinskii mezcal; herbal and green profile
notes: Often used as generic label for several karwinskii forms
source: Karwinskii ethnobotany; mezcal brand technical sheets

geographic_region: Central Valleys of Oaxaca; San Baltazar Guelavila and nearby communities
roesette_pattern: dense rosette on short stem; hillside plant
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike c. 4-6 m; monocarpic; bat and insect pollinated
mezcal_use: Small-batch hillside mezcal maguey; c. 7 year maturation; used for high-proof artisanal mezcal in San Baltazar Guelavila
notes: Unclassified local variety similar to espadín; managed in hillside plots around San Baltazar Guelavila; flavour profile noted as mineral, floral and slightly oily
source: Koch Lumbre and Grulani Lumbre labels; Mezcalistas profile; regional mezcal discussions

geographic_region: High mountains of NE Mexico (Tamaulipas, Nuevo León)
leaf_colour: glossy to dark green with bud-imprint markings
flowering_characteristics: Tall branched spike c. 4-5 m; monocarpic; bat and moth pollinated
mezcal_use: Occasional wild-harvest mountain mezcal in NE Mexico; more often grown as ornamental despite good sugar content
conservation_status: Not evaluated (high-mountain species; locally common in suitable habitat)
notes: Cold-tolerant high-elevation maguey growing in pine-oak forests on steep slopes; likely contributor to future high-altitude mezcal experiments
source: Llifle; nursery descriptions; field notes on Agave montana ecology

geographic_region: Oaxaca central valleys and surrounding sierras
roesette_pattern: large stemless to short stemmed rosette
flowering_characteristics: Very tall spike 6-10 m; monocarpic; bat pollinated
mezcal_use: Huge traditional mezcal agave; big layered spirits
notes: Very large piÃ±as and long maturation (15+ years)
source: Oaxaca agave fichas; mezcal field guides; Food and Wine agave guide

geographic_region: Oaxaca highlands and adjacent states
flowering_characteristics: Tall spike 6-8 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Wild mezcal agave in some regions
notes: Local subvariety of Americana group; often wild harvested
source: Mezcal bar reference lists; ArroqueÃ±o/Sierra Negra descriptions

geographic_region: Oaxaca and neighbouring states
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike c. 6-8 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Hybrid or americana like mezcal agave; rich herbaceous spirits
notes: Name used for several americana or hybrid types depending on village
source: Food and Wine agave species guide; Oaxaca agave fichas
producers: "Creador,Noble Coyote,Mezcal de Leyendas,El Jolgorio,Los Siete Misterios"

geographic_region: From Sonora to Oaxaca, especially Oaxaca mezcal zones
flowering_characteristics: Tall inflorescence 5-7 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: One of main wild and semi cultivated mezcal species; dense oily spirits
conservation_status: Data deficient in IUCN; widely used species
notes: Managed and cultivated in some areas, heavily wild harvested in others
source: CONABIO maguey mexicano ficha; mezcal ecology papers; Food and Wine guide

geographic_region: Durango; Zacatecas; Sierra Madre Occidental
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike c. 5-7 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Regional mezcal species and raicilla relative; rustic profiles
notes: Label used for more than one taxon; data here is schematic
source: Regional mezcal and agave diversity papers

geographic_region: Rio Balsas basin; Guerrero and MichoacÃ¡n
leaf_colour: olive to copper tinged green with reddish spines
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike 4-7 m; monocarpic; seed only reproduction
mezcal_use: Flagship wild mezcal agave of Guerrero and MichoacÃ¡n
notes: No clonal offsets; long maturation (5-15 years); very vulnerable to overharvest
source: IUCN Red List 2020; Kew POWO; Useful Tropical Plants; climate and habitat studies

geographic_region: Central Mexico; Trans Mexican Volcanic Belt (MichoacÃ¡n, Jalisco, Guanajuato)
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike 5-8 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Important regional mezcal species; also domestication ancestor for A. hookeri
notes: Wild and semi managed stands; focus of sustainable harvest research
source: Useful Tropical Plants; Figueredo inaequidens papers; IUCN listing

geographic_region: Central Mexico; Hidalgo; San Luis PotosÃ­; Zacatecas; Guanajuato
flowering_characteristics: Very tall spike up to c. 8-10 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Traditional agave for pulque and regional mezcal; also fibre
notes: Highly productive species adaptable to warmer drier climates
source: Agave salmiana community studies; agave ecology reviews; INIFAP articles

geographic_region: Central Mexico; Hidalgo; San Luis PotosÃ­; Zacatecas; QuerÃ©taro
flowering_characteristics: Tall spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Wild or feral plants harvested for mezcal and fibre
notes: Subject of rangeland and plant community impact studies
source: AusAgave salmiana crassispina profile; plant community research

geographic_region: Northern and central Durango; parts of Zacatecas and Jalisco
flowering_characteristics: Very tall spike 7-8 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Flagship mezcal agave of Durango DO; fruity creamy cenizo mezcals
notes: Endemic medium to large maguey; wild and semi cultivated; key economic species
source: Durango agave notes; Mezcalistas cenizo profile; CONABIO and INIFAP reports
producers: "Sacro Imperio,Mil Lumbres,Mezcal de Leyendas,Lágrimas de Dolores"

geographic_region: Western Michoacán, Mexico, particularly around Sahuayo
flowering_characteristics: Monocarpic, 8-9 m, inflorescence with yellow-green flowers after 10-30 years.
mezcal_use: Cultivated mezcal crop, primary agave for mezcal in Sahuayo region; cultivated with no specific IUCN status but monitored amid demand
notes: Regional mezcal landrace from Sahuayo arid plateaus in western Michoacán; large, glaucous-leaved succulent with robust offsets, prized for high sap yield in “Manso Sahuayo” mezcal.
source: Sahuayo tourism site (ruta-del-mezcal-de-sahuayo), Mezcalistas agave species archive, PMC: Management of domesticated agaves in Michoacán, Spanish Wikipedia: Agave americana, English Wikipedia: Agave americana, NC State Plant Toolbox: Agave americana, PlantZAfrica: Agave americana, NatureServe: Agave americana var. americana, IUCN GISD: Agave americana
producers: "Mezcales de Leyenda,Lamata,Don Mateo de la Sierra"

geographic_region: Western Mexico; Jalisco; Nayarit; Sierra Madre Occidental
flowering_characteristics: Flowering stem 5-8 m; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Key species for raicilla and some mezcal style spirits
notes: Endemic to western Mexico; heavy use for raicilla with sustainability concerns
source: Useful Tropical Plants; raicilla and maximiliana reviews; PictureThis and Seedaholic profiles
producers: "Raicilla De Una,Estancia Raicilla,Fidencio Spirits,Maguey Melate,Raicilla Perra Suerte"

geographic_region: Sierra Madre Occidental (Sonora; Chihuahua, adjacent states)
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Local mezcal and related distillates in some Sierra Madre communities
notes: Cold tolerant high elevation agave; also used for fibre
source: Useful Tropical Plants; regional floras for A. shrevei

geographic_region: Tequila region Jalisco and other tequila DO states; limited mezcal DO areas
flowering_characteristics: Flowering usually suppressed in fields; wild plants with tall spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Main tequila species; occasionally used in mezcal in certain regions
notes: Highly domesticated monoculture crop; genetic erosion an issue
source: Tequilana ecology and cultivation papers; Llifle and tequila DO info

geographic_region: Northern highlands of Nuevo LeÃ³n and Coahuila; Sierra Madre Oriental
flowering_characteristics: Tall paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Local mezcal and regional spirits; also ornamental and forage
notes: Northern mezcal species with limited but growing recognition
source: AusAgave gentryi profile; northern Mexico agave surveys

geographic_region: Guerrero, Mexico
flowering_characteristics: Slow-moderate growing shrub-like succulent; monocarpic with tall inflorescence (6-8 m) bearing flowers after 8-11 years, reproducing by seed and offsets.
mezcal_use: Valued for high-yield, organoleptic-quality mezcal in Guerrero; emerging commercial potential amid limited cultivation.
notes: Crimson spire agave from Guerrero rocky terrains; variable rosette size with robust, spiny pencas suited to marginal edaphoclimatic zones.
source: SciELO agroecological studies, Useful Tropical Plants.

geographic_region: Oaxaca (Miahuatlán, Logoche)
flowering_characteristics: Slow-growing with limited offsets; monocarpic after 15-25 years, producing tall branched inflorescence with yellow flowers.
mezcal_use: Only niche artisanal mezcals (e.g., Neta Rayo) exist from homegrown plants, making it one of Oaxaca’s rarest commercial agaves with no widespread production. Unlike common variants like Espadín, Rayo represents a critically endangered cultivar preserved by dedicated mezcaleros.
conservation_status: Not evaluated (local concern - nearly extinct wild).
notes: Obsidian-spined century plant landrace from Miahuatlán; narrow leaves and jet-black terminal spines create “lightning” silhouette; preserved from extinction by single mezcalero family.
source: Neta Spirits, Mezcal Reviews, Miahuatlán agave studies.

geographic_region: Yucatán Peninsula, southern Mexico
flowering_characteristics: Moderate-growing industrial fiber crop propagated by suckers; monocarpic, producing a 6 m stalk with greenish-white flowers after 15-30 years, yielding bulbils.
mezcal_use: Major plantation crop for henequen fiber (ropes, twine); fermented piña used for regional mezcal and pulque; widely cultivated.
notes: Hardy fiber agave from Yucatán lowlands; industrial-scale plantations with durable leaves harvested twice yearly for 20+ years.
source: Britannica, Wikipedia, PFAF databases.

geographic_region: Western Mexico; Pacific slope Sierra Madre Occidental
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Traditional mezcal and raicilla like spirits in western Mexico
notes: Western analogue to other mezcal agaves; taxonomy recently clarified
source: Regional raicilla and mezcal texts; western Mexico floras

geographic_region: Sierra Madre Occidental (north west Mexico)
flowering_characteristics: Tall inflorescence; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Local mezcal style spirits; minor but documented mezcal species
notes: Very little popular information; known through floristic and mezcal surveys
source: Sierra Madre Occidental agave and mezcal inventories

geographic_region: Oaxaca; Guerrero and nearby states
flowering_characteristics: Tall spike; very foamy must; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Notoriously difficult mezcal species due to saponins; wild harvested
notes: Produces highly characterful but low yield mezcals; often blended
source: Food and Wine agave species guide; producer technical notes

geographic_region: Yucatán Peninsula, southern Mexico
flowering_characteristics: Moderate-growing industrial fiber crop propagated by suckers; monocarpic, producing a 6 m stalk with greenish-white flowers after 15-30 years, yielding bulbils.
mezcal_use: Major plantation crop for henequen fiber (ropes, twine); fermented piña used for regional mezcal and pulque; widely cultivated.
notes: Hardy fiber agave from Yucatán lowlands; industrial-scale plantations with durable leaves harvested twice yearly for 20+ years.
source: Britannica, Wikipedia, PFAF databases.
producers: "Mil Lumbres,Ultramundo,De Matachines,Maguey Melate,Burrito Fiestero,Lagrimas de Dolores"

geographic_region: Oaxaca and Sierra Madre regions
flowering_characteristics: Paniculate spike; monocarpic
mezcal_use: Wild form of angustifolia used for rustic mezcals
notes: Name usually signals non plantation, more rugged angustifolia stands
source: Angustifolia ecology papers; Oaxaca maguey fichas
producers: "Lamata,Lagrimas de Dolores,Burrito,Rayo Blanco,Reyo Seco,Hacienda de Bañuelos"

geographic_region: Chihuahua, Durango, Sinaloa
flowering_characteristics: Slow-growing cliff-dweller producing few offsets; monocarpic with tall (5-6 m) spike of light green flowers after 10-20 years.
mezcal_use: Ornamental with potential beverage use; wild-harvested sparingly due to remote habitats, valued for striking fibrous leaves.
notes: Filamentous threadleaf agave from Sierra Madre cliffs; extreme xerophyte with dense white marginal curls protecting against desiccation and herbivores.
source: Plant Delights, POWO, regional nurseries

geographic_region: TehuacÃ¡n-CuicatlÃ¡n region; Puebla & Oaxaca; Mexico
flowering_characteristics: Tall panicle to 3-4 m after 10-15 years; then rosette dies
mezcal_use: Wild and semi managed mezcal agave; produces bright structured mezcals
notes: Small striking mezcalero agave from Ixcateco / TehuacÃ¡n slopes; valued for concentrated sugars and mineral character
source: Useful Tropical Plants; Mezcalistas macroacantha profile; regional floras

geographic_region: Yautepec district and cultivated mezcal zones of Oaxaca; also grown for fibre elsewhere
roesette_pattern: short stemmed rosette with arching leaves
flowering_characteristics: Massive flowering stalk to 6-8 m; monocarpic but offsets from base
mezcal_use: Traditional regional mezcal and agave spirit; more often known for fibre but used locally for rustic mezcals
conservation_status: Not formally assessed; widely cultivated and not considered threatened in mezcal range
notes: Historic fibre maguey adopted into local mezcal production; gives dense rustic spirits when mature plants are used
source: Useful Tropical Plants; fibre crop guides; regional mezcal producer notes on maguey cincoaÃ±ero

geographic_region: Central Mexico (notably State of Mexico and Balsas / Bajío region mentions)
leaf_shape: broad lanceolate to oblong, relatively flattened rosette (consistent with A. applanata “applanate/flattened” habit).
roesette_pattern: medium to large, fairly open, flattened rosette with erect–spreading leaves and prominent marginal teeth and terminal spine
flowering_characteristics: Monocarpic; after 10–15+ years forms a tall, branched inflorescence with numerous yellowish flowers, then dies (typical of mezcalero agaves in this complex).
mezcal_use: Used for mezcal in several regions; described as a close relative of Espadín/Oaxacensis, generally smaller, with wild plants often harvested for specialty mezcals labeled Castilla.
notes: Wild mezcal agave known as maguey de Castilla or maguey Castilla; mid-sized, Espadín-like plant often found in foothill and dry forest ecotones, valued for distinctive, terroir-expressive mezcals and typically described as smaller and more purely wild than Espadín.
source: Mexican mezcal producer and review sites, biodiversity and flora portals (EncicloVida, iNaturalist) that equate Castilla with Agave applanata.

geographic_region: Sierra Sur and Chontal Sierra of Oaxaca; mezcal producers reference communities such as Santiago Matatlán, Santa María Ecatepec, and nearby mountainous areas.
leaf_shape: narrow to medium-width lanceolate leaves, intermediate between slim A. angustifolia “espadín” and broader A. americana; erect-arching, forming a strong upright rosette
roesette_pattern: large, robust rosette with many leaves; more open and upright than typical espadín.
flowering_characteristics: monocarpic; after roughly 10–15+ years, produces a tall, branched inflorescence bearing numerous yellowish flowers, then the mother rosette dies, as in both parent species
mezcal_use: Used specifically for small-batch, wild or semi-wild mezcals labeled “Chuparrosa,” with producers describing distinctive floral, spicy, and subtly sweet profiles.
notes: Wild mezcal agave from highland Oaxaca, taxonomically unresolved (often recorded simply as Agave sp. “Chuparrosa”), showing intermediate morphology between A. angustifolia and A. americana and valued for complex, floral–spiced mezcal with limited, small-scale production.
source: Mezcal Reviews – Dixeebe Chuparrosa , Old Town Tequila – Dixeebe Chuparrosa Mezcal , Mezcal Amarás Logia Chuparrosa – product/brand page , Maestros Selectos – CHUPARROSA agave info , Various retail/brand listings for Chuparrosa mezcal (e.g., Moreno’s, Drinqy, social posts) , Scientific and technical papers on Agave angustifolia (micropropagation, morphology, management) , Descriptive resources on Agave angustifolia for mezcal (Mezcología) , General references on Agave americana biology and uses (encyclopedic and plant databases)

geographic_region: Oaxaca, Puebla, Veracruz
flowering_characteristics: slow-growing giant producing offsets (hijuelos); monocarpic after 8-12 years, sending up enormous 12+ m scape with red-to-yellow flowers in panicle
mezcal_use: Primary species for pulque production (fermented sap); also mezcal base and medicinal; traditionally managed in agroforestry.
notes: Giant pulque agave of Mexican highlands; largest native agave rosettes with immense sap yield from tapped flower stalks.
source: Wikipedia, iNaturalist, EncicloVida, Useful Tropical Plants.

geographic_region: Oaxaca (Miahuatlán, Logoche)
flowering_characteristics: slow-growing with offsets; monocarpic after 10-30 years, producing massive 8-9 m branched inflorescence with yellow flowers prior to sap extraction.
mezcal_use: Selected specifically for aguamiel (pulque sap) production through heart-tapping; also distilled as regional mezcal; widely cultivated in traditional systems.
notes: Pulque-specialized landrace of century plant from Oaxacan highlands; human-selected for massive sap production. Rare, hyper-local bottlings not found in commercial-scale production.
source: Neta Spirits, Mezcal Reviews, CONABIO agave fichas.
